awd_titl_txt: Magnetic Field Advection in High Energy Density Plasmas Produced by Radial Foil Configurations
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing sustainable clean energy sources, studying the degenerate states of matter or understanding the dynamics of the Universe require a detailed knowledge of the basic mechanisms ruling extremely high pressure ionized gases, also called high energy density (HED) plasmas.  In particular, the advection of the magnetic field by HED plasmas remains an open question to the international scientific community.  This research program investigates this topic using radial foil configurations.  In this experimental arrangement, a thin metallic foil is driven by a large pulsed power generator.  A pin cathode contacts the foil at its geometrical center while the foil periphery is connected to a circular anode.  The converging electrical currents produce a plasma pressure close to a mega-bar, a million times the earth atmospheric pressure.  The experimental setup benefits from quasi symmetric plasma dynamics and excellent diagnostic access.  This configuration permits a three dimensional reconstruction of plasma properties such as magnetic field, mass density, velocity and temperature.  By combining multiple measurements spaced in time, this research analyzes the time evolution of the plasma parameters and highlights the mechanisms ruling magnetic field advection in HED plasmas.

This research program also impacts other area of plasma physics.  We plan to compare experimental results to numerical computations to validate advanced plasma models.  As plasma theory and numerical modeling can be used by the larger plasma physics community, this research will benefit other areas of plasma research, such as magnetic confinement fusion.  Furthermore, the research investigates the interaction of the magnetic field with supersonic plasma flows, which are ubiquitous astrophysical occurrences encountered in supernovae and accretion disks surrounding black holes.  Due to favorable scaling laws, plasmas generated by radial foils can help to unlock astrophysical mechanisms by providing detailed plasma measurements in supersonic regimes.  In turn, this data can be used to validate astrophysical theory and numerical codes, fostering cross-pollination between the HED physics and astrophysics communities.

por.por_cntn:
The project entitled “Magnetic Field Advection in High Energy Density Plasmas” undertakes exploratory plasma physics experiments in the High Energy Density (HED) regime to better understand the physical mechanisms that drive magnetized plasma flows. The experiments are carried out on the Cornell COBRA device, which is a 1 MA 100 ns rise time pulsed power machine that can generate dense plasmas that of interest to the inertial confinement fusion and astrophysical communities. Experiments typically involve metal foils driven in various geometrical configurations such as to produce high magnetic Mach number flows. The value of these experiments is greatly enhanced through the use and development of state-of-the-art diagnostics and advanced computer codes that can capture the relevant physics. The interaction of experimentalists and simulationists provides a synergy that has been essential in the interpretation of the experimental as well as simulation results. The result is a new understanding of the dynamical importance of physical effects generally considered unimportant by the community at large, at least in the HED regime.  A summary of these effects follows.

In HED plasma physics most computer models utilize a magnetohydrodynamical (MHD) fluid description with transport physics to include effects of resistivity, thermal conductivity, equations of state, ionization and radiation. The MHD model omits an effect called the Hall effect that is extremely difficult to include in simulations due to its computational expense.  Hence, even very large computers have great difficulty in including this effect in the HED regime; therefore it is almost always neglected, with the justification being that it is unimportant at the high densities encountered in the HED plasma regime. Our experimental and simulation results have conclusively shown that the importance of the Hall effect in HED plasmas has been greatly underestimated and that the results of a number of experiments can only be explained when it is included in the simulation model.  At Cornell we are fortunate to have developed a plasma fluid simulation code that includes the Hall effect and other effects that are difficult to compute efficiently. The code is called PERSEUS and solves the extended-MHD (XMHD) equations, which includes the Hall effect. The advance that made this possible was the development of an algorithm that enables the inclusion of the XMHD (non-MHD) effects in a manner that is computationally efficient, enabling the simulation study of effects that were previously unattainable in the HED regime.

Over the course of this project we have identified a number of effects that are readily diagnosed in HED experiments and subsequently verified as having an origin in Hall effect. We have also identified a simulation result due to the Hall effect which was subsequently detected in the experiments. An example of the latter is shown in Figure 1. There are a number of additional features in experiments that are attributable to the Hall effect and our understanding of these has improved immensely over the course of this project. Our ultimate goal is to motivate the HED community to include these physical effects into their large-scale laboratory codes and utilize an algorithm that enables efficient simulation of XMHD HED phenomena.
